title: Hospitals Fear Abortion Bans Will Worsen Staff Shortages (1)
description: Some doctors don’t even want to think about taking jobs in Texas, Wyoming, or other states with strict abortion bans, raising questions about how hospitals will recruit and retain medical staff in a post-Roe country.

Photographer: Cheney Orr/Bloomberg   PrintEmailShare To:FacebookLinkedInAug. 9, 2022, 9:00 AM UTC; Updated: Aug. 9, 2022, 2:46 PM UTCHospitals Fear Abortion Bans Will Worsen Staff Shortages (1)By Jennifer Kay Jennifer Kay Staff CorrespondentOut-of-state hiring has become tougher, recruiters say Cleveland Clinic expects to lose staff over abortion lawSome doctors don’t even want to think about taking jobs in Texas, Wyoming, or other states with strict abortion bans, raising questions about how hospitals will recruit and retain medical staff in a post-Roe country.Specialists in obstetrics and gynecology—frequent targets of medical malpractice lawsuits—especially are wary of taking jobs in states where the laws could limit their practice, according to recruiters for Merritt Hawkins, AMN Healthcare’s physician recruiting division.“They are fearful,” said Tom Florence, executive vice president of recruiting for Merritt Hawkins.
